Package io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics

Interface State<BUILDER,HISTORY,STATE,X extends State<BUILDER,HISTORY,STATE,X>>

Type Parameters:
BUILDER - builder of either outbreak state (policy) or person state (behaviour).
HISTORY - builder of either outbreak history (policy) or person history (behaviour).
STATE - the current state of the entity (e.g. OutbreakState (policy) or behaviour state)
X - the super-type of allowable state models.
All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
BehaviourModel, PolicyModel, State.BehaviourState, State.PolicyState, StateUtils.DefaultNoTesting, StateUtils.DoesPCRIfSymptomatic
All Known Implementing Classes:
LockdownIsolation, NoControl, NonCompliant, ReactiveLockdown, ReactiveTestAndIsolate, SmartAgentLFTTesting, SmartAgentTesting, Symptomatic, Test
public interface State<BUILDER,HISTORY,STATE,X extends State<BUILDER,HISTORY,STATE,X>> extends Serializable
This abstraction lets us have policy and behaviour models sharing the same state model framework, so outbreak and person updates can follow the same pattern. This is the super-type for State.PolicyState and State.BehaviourState.

Each state machine state has 2 methods in it that alter the behaviour of the outbreak or agent. firstly the updateHistory(Object, Object, StateMachineContext, Sampler) method which is run at the end of each day and allows the population of data points that are specific to PersonHistory or OutbreakHistory. Usually this means

    State.PolicyState
    Marks a state model state as being a component of a policy for managing to the outbreak simulation as a whole

  • Method Details

    • getEnumClass

      default Class<State<BUILDER,HISTORY,STATE,X>> getEnumClass()
      The states in the state model are all enum fields. This provides a hook back into the definition so we can tell if it is a policy or behaviour model state. This is largely used for displaying the name of the policy or behaviour model from the individual state it is in.
      Returns:
      the class of the Enum of this policy or behaviour state.

    • getName

      default String getName()
      The name of the state, which is the enum name prefixed by the enum class name. This is used for display purposes, and to make it clear which model a state belongs to when looking at the state of an individual person or the outbreak.
      Returns:
      the name of the state, which is the enum name prefixed by the enum class name.

    • name

      String name()
      The name of the model that this state belongs to, which is the enum class name. This is used for display purposes, and to make it clear which model a state belongs to when looking at the state of an individual person or the outbreak.
      Returns:
      the name of the model that this state belongs to, which is the enum class name.

    • nextState

      X nextState(BUILDER builder, STATE current, StateMachineContext context, Sampler rng)
      This is the hook for changing the behaviour in the model in terms of mobility, compliance etc in person/behavioural models, or changing system wide properties in outbreak/policy models. These changes can be thought of as happening at the start of a day in relation to the information available from the day before. Because of this limitation it is difficult for the model to react to things that happen on the same day. To some extent reflex testing is possible as the result of a test can be known instantly.

      This method both decides what the future behaviour or policy will be based on the current state, but can also change the future state by calling the builder parameter's methods. This is the main place in which future state is affected by behaviour, and a lot of the effects are implemented as static methods in StateUtils.

      The implementation of the nextState method in policy models can influence both the next state of the Outbreak (via the builder) but also can influence the next state of people within the outbreak indirectly by iterating through the agents and calling StateUtils.branchPeopleTo(io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState, io.github.ai4ci.abm.mechanics.StateMachine.BehaviourState) which will force an immediate change in the individuals persons behaviour model state, Person.getStateMachine() on each of them.

      Other changes are possible by interacting with Person.getNextState() (the next person state builder, which will be populated by the time this method is called). Changes made in this way by a policy model could be changed back if dictated by the person's behaviour model so this is less reliable than authoring a behaviour that specifically updates the persons state in response to a policy state change.
      Parameters:
      builder - the builder for the future state of the agent or outbreak.
      current - the current state of the agent or outbreak.
      context - the previous states and other context for the state model
      rng - a random number generator
      Returns:
      The behaviour or policy state for the next time step, but side effects on the state of the builder are expected.

    • updateHistory

      void updateHistory(HISTORY builder, STATE current, StateMachineContext context, Sampler rng)
      Depending on the type this updated the outbreak or person history, and this is the hook for changing the testing, or adding in contacts / exposures if we are looking at people. Use case is less clear for outbreak/policy, as there is less stored here. The implementation for outbreak (PolicyModel) makes this a no-op. This is called during the history stage of the update cycle, and effectively performs actions that are done at the end of the day.
      Parameters:
      builder - the next PersonHistory builder (usually)
      current - the current PersonHistory
      context - the previous states and other context for the state model
      rng - the sampler
